pullRequest.body:
This PR proves two basic results about the complex exponential:
* `abs_exp_mul_I (x : ℂ) : abs (Complex.exp (I * x)) = Real.exp (-x.im)`
* `one_sub_rexp_re_le_abs_one_sub_cexp (x : ℂ) : 1 - Real.exp x.re ≤ Complex.abs (1 - Complex.exp x)`
Both results were proved as part of the sphere packing project. There's a chance they're too specific for mathlib, but I thought they were worth PRing anyway. Would it also be a good idea to tag `abs_exp_mul_I` with `simp`? Feedback/suggestions welcome.

Note: `one_sub_rexp_re_le_abs_one_sub_cexp` was proved by Bhavik Mehta @b-mehta 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body: messageFile.md

Yes, you could add `@[simp]`.

The theorem names in the PR description don't match the PR.
Any chance you'd be interested in splitting this file into smaller pieces? Every `set_option longFile` we merge is adding work for someone! :-)

> Any chance you'd be interested in splitting this file into smaller pieces? Every `set_option longFile` we merge is adding work for someone! :-)

Sure! What do you think would be a good way of doing this?

I'm a fairly new contributor to Mathlib, but I do have a few thoughts. Perhaps we can create a folder called Exponential to replace the file. We can then split this file into two files that live inside that folder, one with the definitions of the various functions defined (lines 24-146) and another with the statements about these functions. If we want, the file with all the statements can be further subdivided into files like "Basic" and such, each roughly corresponding to a part of the file where one namespace is closed and another is opened. Another (and possibly more sensible, if also more laborious) way of splitting it up would be to group together lemmas about each of the functions defined, though there is a bit of overlap... in any case, just having two files would solve the _immediate_ problem of having a file over 1500 lines long, but if we can expect to merge more results about the exponential and related functions, it might be good to divide the files up.

> Yes, you could add `@[simp]`.

Done!

> The theorem names in the PR description don't match the PR.

Apologies, forgot to change it when renaming the theorem. Changed it now.
My guess is that it makes more sense to make `Complex.abs_exp` simp, since that's syntactically more general. And then the lhs of this one won't be in simp normal form, so it shouldn't be simp.

> > Any chance you'd be interested in splitting this file into smaller pieces? Every `set_option longFile` we merge is adding work for someone! :-)
> 
> Sure! What do you think would be a good way of doing this?
> 
> I'm a fairly new contributor to Mathlib, but I do have a few thoughts. Perhaps we can create a folder called Exponential to replace the file. We can then split this file into two files that live inside that folder, one with the definitions of the various functions defined (lines 24-146) and another with the statements about these functions. If we want, the file with all the statements can be further subdivided into files like "Basic" and such, each roughly corresponding to a part of the file where one namespace is closed and another is opened. Another (and possibly more sensible, if also more laborious) way of splitting it up would be to group together lemmas about each of the functions defined, though there is a bit of overlap... in any case, just having two files would solve the _immediate_ problem of having a file over 1500 lines long, but if we can expect to merge more results about the exponential and related functions, it might be good to divide the files up.

I think starting with the two file split is best, as Exponential/Defs and Exponential/Lemmas, and then feel invited in a subsequent PR to split Lemmas further!

> My guess is that it makes more sense to make `Complex.abs_exp` simp, since that's syntactically more general. And then the lhs of this one won't be in simp normal form, so it shouldn't be simp.

I've made the change and shortened the proofs. `abs_exp_eq_iff_re_eq` is also now a `simp` proof.
@thefundamentaltheor3m Is your intention to split the file in this PR or in a following one?

> @thefundamentaltheor3m Is your intention to split the file in this PR or in a following one?

Apologies, I missed this comment. Yes, I thought this split could be done here so as to avoid having a long file in the library. However, it might be a while before I can fix all the resulting errors...

1. Please replace the `I * x` in the theorem with `x * I` to follow the conventions of the rest of the file.
2. There is no need to write `Complex.exp`; it can be replaced simply by `exp`.
3. The name of the theorem should contain the word `mul` to indicate the multiplication; for example, `abs_exp_mul_I`.
4. The proof can be reduced to one line: `simp [Complex.abs_exp, Complex.mul_re]`.

1. There is no need to write `Complex.exp` or `Complex.abs`; they can be replaced simply by `exp` and `abs`.
2. Simplify the proof by using [IsAbsoluteValue.sub_abv_le_abv_sub](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Order/AbsoluteValue.html#IsAbsoluteValue.sub_abv_le_abv_sub).

pullRequest.title: feat(Data/Complex/Exponential): prove some useful results about the complex exponential.
